text:
Hey Callum! How’s it going?
hope you had a nice weekend.

I had a look at your reel. good work!
nicely presented

Lets look at your questions

How did you get your first job as a compositor?
When I was a student I would take up compositing tasks with friends(like little aspirational projects with friends), make short films(and volunteer to do the compositing) eventually leading to freelance work.
Managed to put together a portfolio upon graduation, Interviewed at a few places and found work at a film vfx company which had just started using nuke.

What was it like working at DNEG and Framestore?
The Vibe is similar between both the companies. I have had the opportunity to work on cool stuff at both places.

Did you work at DNEG in London?
Yes I worked in London for a bit before moving to Canada. The DNEG Office is cool with some nice coffee and relaxed atmosphere.

What are companies looking for in a graduate compositor showreel?
-Examples of relevant work.
-Potential to do great things

What should I be practising?
-Compositing
-Try filming something and experimenting with it(a phone or a borrowed camera whatever is available). Make it look cool! be the director

Have you ever been to FMX? If you have, what is it like?
-I haven’t visited FMX but I have been to Siggraph, You get to see lots of active research. Meet/Network with different people, talk to recruiters and ofcourse find a job. I would expect FMX would be on similar lines

Do you use Nuke at Framestore?
everyday, all day.

What kind of stuff are you working on at Framestore?
This year it has been quite a bit of Environments but also CG characters. Currently we are working on a film called Lady and the Tramp. 

Do you have any general tips for me?
Yes! Keep an open eye and observe.
Reality is complex so is cinematic “reality”
filmed through a lens with a camera.
Practice making pretty pictures with tools you have, learn new things as you go.
Keep it simple!
